TopicTitle: [Invention] Discussion on location of the Kerbol system.

Articles.Content:
The poll is if suddenly the KSP dev team decides to add somewhat of a storyline. If not, this is Fan Fiction!

Plaatinum Aerospace Technologies
I\'ve always been partial to the idea that the system is located in an alternate universe with different physical laws.

I\'ve always been partial to the idea that the system is located in an alternate universe with different physical laws.

You\'re not the only one, I was thinking the same thing.
I also like the 'fictional universe'. I just wanted to know what other people thought

I\'ve always been partial to the idea that the system is located in an alternate universe with different physical laws.

That\'s what I thought, too. The laws of physics are essentially the same as ours, except for a couple of subtle differences like everything has substantially more mass in the kerbal universe.
Well, if the universe has four spatial dimensions, this might all be in a different 3D slice than our own

Yeah, the 'other universe' is a good explanation for why a tiny 600 KM sphere has a gravity as strong as Earth\'s one.

And why everything simply explodes when destroyed 8)

Possibly, the disrepancy between mass, size, and physics could be resolved by placing the system in a different universe based around magnetic monopoles instead of normal atoms. These would have much, much more mass/cm3 than normal matter.
Different universe, where the dominant element is Explodium which has about 11 times more mass than the materials of Earth.
I too agree with the alternate Universe idea. Perhaps in the Kerbal\'s Universe, the Higs-field is much more powerful, thus resulting in more mass.
